sentence: Since mobile phones need to be charged with electricity to work, and Benjamin Franklin invented electricity, and people had mobile phones before Franklin, therefore people before Franklin didn't have access to mobile phones
details: The argument contains multiple logical errors. First, the premise that 'Benjamin Franklin invented electricity' is factually incorrect (false premise). Second, the conclusion that 'people before Franklin didn't have access to mobile phones' is based on a false causal relationship (false cause), as mobile phones did not exist before Franklin's time, making the reasoning circular. Additionally, the argument incorrectly reverses the timeline (wrong direction) by suggesting mobile phones existed before electricity was harnessed.

sentence: Since atomic bombs mean weapons of mass destruction, and atomic bombs means bombs as small as atoms, and atomic  is a substance so small that it cannot be seen,and the bigger the bomb the more powerful it is, therefore atomic bombs do not do any damage.
details: The sentence contains multiple logical errors. First, it equivocates on the term 'atomic bombs,' using it to mean both 'weapons of mass destruction' and 'bombs as small as atoms,' which are contradictory definitions. Second, it relies on a false premise by incorrectly defining 'atomic' as something too small to see, ignoring the actual destructive power of atomic bombs. Third, it makes a false analogy by assuming that because atoms are small, atomic bombs must also be small and harmless, which is incorrect. The conclusion that atomic bombs do no damage is absurd and contradicts known facts.

sentence: Since heat kills germs, and people get sick from germs,  and cooking makes heat, and people will be alive after cooking, therefore people who are sick can kill germs by cooking themselves.
details: The argument commits multiple logical errors. First, it falsely analogizes cooking food (which kills germs in the food) to cooking humans (which would not have the same effect and is absurd). Second, it assumes a false cause—just because heat kills germs in food does not mean applying heat to humans would cure illness. Third, it improperly transposes the idea that 'heat kills germs in food' to 'heat kills germs in humans,' ignoring the vast differences in context. The conclusion is nonsensical and dangerous.

sentence: Since tobacco is unhealthy, and vegetables are healthy, and cigarettes are made of tobacco, and vegetables can be used to make cigarettes, therefore the cigarettes which are made of vegetable are healthy.
details: The argument commits a false analogy by assuming that because vegetables are healthy and can be used to make cigarettes, the resulting cigarettes must also be healthy—ignoring other factors like processing and combustion effects. It also commits a fallacy of composition by assuming that the healthiness of individual components (vegetables) directly translates to the healthiness of the whole product (vegetable cigarettes). Additionally, the premise that 'vegetables can be used to make cigarettes' is misleading, as typical cigarettes are not made primarily from vegetables, making it a false premise.

sentence: If trains are operated by conductors, and superconductors are 'super' conductors, and superconductors are better conductors, and superconductors also mean materials with zero resistance, then superconductors should be running the trains instead.
details: The argument commits multiple logical errors. First, it equivocates on the word 'conductor,' using it in two different senses (train conductors vs. electrical conductors). Second, it makes a false analogy by assuming that because superconductors are better at conducting electricity, they should also be better at operating trains, which is nonsensical. Finally, it commits a nominal fallacy by treating the metaphorical use of 'super' in 'superconductor' as if it literally means 'better at conducting trains.'

sentence: Since contact lenses allow to see out of the lenses, therefore putting contacts in backwards will be able to see the thinking.
details: The sentence contains multiple logical errors. First, it makes a false analogy by assuming that because contact lenses allow vision outward, reversing them would allow seeing 'thinking' (an unrelated concept). Second, it relies on a false premise that seeing 'thinking' is even possible through lenses. Third, it equivocates by using 'see' in both a literal and metaphorical sense without clarification.

sentence: Since vacuum means space without air or matter, and vacuum also means dust catcher, and space is vacuum, therefore space can clean up the Earth.
details: The argument commits the fallacy of equivocation by using the word 'vacuum' in two different senses (a space devoid of matter vs. a cleaning device). It also makes a false analogy by assuming that because a household vacuum cleaner can 'clean,' the vacuum of space must also have cleaning properties, despite the two concepts being fundamentally different.

sentence: Since negative number times negative number is a positive number in the math, and the national debt is a negative number, and the national debt times the national debt will become positive, and a positive national debt means making money, therefore multiply the national debt by more debt means making money.
details: The argument commits multiple logical errors. First, it falsely analogizes mathematical operations (negative × negative = positive) to economic concepts (national debt), ignoring the real-world implications of debt. Second, it relies on a false premise by assuming that 'national debt' can be treated as a pure mathematical negative number without economic context. Third, it equivocates by conflating the mathematical positivity from multiplication with the economic concept of 'making money,' which are not equivalent.

sentence: If 4/3 is more than 100%, and a population cannot be described as more than 100%, and I believe that 4/3 of Americans have trouble with fractions, and I am American, then 4/3 of Americans must have trouble with fractions.
details: The argument contains multiple logical errors. First, it relies on a false premise—that a population can be described as '4/3' (133.33%), which is mathematically impossible (a population cannot exceed 100%). Second, it presents a false dilemma by suggesting that because 4/3 is more than 100%, and populations cannot exceed 100%, the conclusion must follow—ignoring other possible interpretations or corrections. Third, it begs the question by assuming the truth of its own premise ('I believe that 4/3 of Americans have trouble with fractions') without independent evidence, then using it to justify the conclusion.

sentence: Since 'shoot the breeze' means feel free to chat, and it also means shoot the wind with a gun, therefore 'shoot the breeze' means the wind will suffer.
details: The sentence commits an equivocation by treating the idiomatic phrase 'shoot the breeze' (meaning to chat casually) as if it could also be interpreted literally (shooting the wind with a gun). This leads to a nonsensical conclusion. Additionally, it exhibits a nominal fallacy by misinterpreting a metaphorical expression as a literal statement.

sentence: Since I can plainly see that the Titanic took on water and sank, and I can have easily spotted the design flaws, and engineers a hundred years ago did not see this comingtherefore, and the one who discovers the problem first is more professional, therefore I am more professional than those engineers.
details: The sentence contains several logical errors. First, it assumes that discovering a problem first implies greater professionalism, which is a 'false cause' fallacy because the timing of discovery does not necessarily correlate with professionalism. Second, it 'begs the question' by assuming that being first to discover a problem makes one more professional without providing evidence. Third, it relies on a 'false premise' that professional superiority is determined solely by the order of problem discovery.

sentence: Since “dead” means death and also disappearance, and 'dead language' means the language of the disappeared but it can also be the language of the dead, therefore speaking a dead language allows you to talk to the dead.
details: The argument commits equivocation by exploiting the multiple meanings of 'dead' (literal death vs. disappearance) to create a misleading connection between 'dead language' and communication with the dead. It also engages in a false analogy by assuming that because a language is called 'dead,' it must literally be used by the dead. Additionally, the conclusion is based on a false premise that speaking a dead language inherently enables communication with deceased individuals, which is an unfounded assumption.

sentence: Since the amount of gold that humans have mined throughout history can be analogised to 3.42 olympic pools, and the total amount of gold changes with the size of the pool, therefore the bigger the pool the more gold.
details: The argument commits a false analogy by comparing the total amount of gold mined to the volume of Olympic pools, implying that increasing the pool size would increase the gold supply, which is not logically connected. Additionally, it suggests a false cause by implying that pool size affects gold quantity, which is unrelated.

sentence: If power plants generate electricity, and electricity is needed to run things, and power plants use electricity to generate electricity, and plants are also living creatures that can be planted, then planting more power plants should solve the energy crisis.
details: The sentence contains multiple logical errors. First, it falsely equates 'power plants' (industrial facilities) with 'plants' (living organisms), which is a false analogy. Second, it equivocates by using the word 'plants' in two different senses without clarification. Third, it relies on a false premise that power plants use electricity to generate electricity, which is misleading or incorrect in most contexts (they typically use fuel or other energy sources). The conclusion that 'planting more power plants' would solve the energy crisis is nonsensical due to these errors.

sentence: Since shelf-life means how long food can stay on a shelf before it expires, food on the floor means food will not stay on a shelf and will not have shelf-life, therefore food on the floor will not expire.
details: The argument commits multiple logical errors. First, it equivocates on the term 'shelf-life,' treating it as strictly literal (requiring an actual shelf) rather than its intended meaning (duration before spoilage). Second, it relies on a false premise that food not on a shelf cannot expire, which is factually incorrect. Third, it makes a false analogy by assuming that the conditions defining shelf-life (placement on a shelf) must apply universally to all food, ignoring other factors affecting spoilage (e.g., time, temperature).

sentence: Since I flip a coin 1,000,000 times, and a coin can be used to calculate probabilities, and flipping a coin 1,000,000 times is time-consuming, therefore I still need a coin to calculate the probability of wasting time by flipping a coin 1,000,000 times.
details: The argument contains several logical errors. First, it assumes a false cause by suggesting that flipping a coin 1,000,000 times is necessary to calculate the probability of wasting time, when simpler methods exist. Second, it begs the question by assuming the conclusion (needing a coin to calculate probability) within the premise. Third, it equivocates by using 'coin' both as a physical object for flipping and as a tool for probability calculation, creating ambiguity.

sentence: If someone is shot every 15 seconds in America, and 'someone' also means the same person each time, and mortal people die after a single shot, then that person must be immortal.
details: The argument contains multiple logical errors. First, it relies on a false premise by assuming that 'someone' must refer to the same person each time, which is not necessarily true (equivocation). Second, it presents a false dilemma by suggesting that the only possible conclusion is that the person is immortal, ignoring other explanations (e.g., different people being shot each time). The reasoning is flawed because it misuses language and makes unjustified assumptions.
